'''The Tolkien Trust''' is a British charity founded in [[1977]] by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s children. As a charitable trust, it makes grants to a wide variety of organisations at the discretion of the current trustees.<ref>{{webcite|articleurl=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1150801&SubsidiaryNumber=0|articlename=Charity overview - The Tolkien Trust|accessed=7 July 2015|website=[https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/charity-commission Charity Commission]}}</ref> It does not manage Tolkien's literary estate,<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.tolkientrust.org/ The Tolkien Trust]|articleurl=http://www.tolkientrust.org/faqs.html|articlename=FAQ|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> even though its source of income is via the copyright it owns to some of Tolkien's works that were formerly owned by The [[Tolkien Estate]].

==Activities==
Created on [[1 April]] [[1977]], and registered with the Charity Commission from [[2 June]] [[1977]], the Trust was founded by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s four children: [[John Tolkien|John]], [[Michael Tolkien|Michael]], [[Christopher Tolkien|Christopher]] and [[Priscilla Tolkien|Priscilla]]. Today, the trustees of the charity are Christopher, Priscilla, [[Michael George Tolkien]] (son of Michael, succeeding his sister Joan as a trustee in 2008),<ref name="Accounts2009"/> and Christopher's wife [[Baillie Tolkien]].<ref>{{webcite|articleurl=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/ContactAndTrustees.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1150801&SubsidiaryNumber=0|articlename=Contact and trustees - The Tolkien Trust|accessed=7 July 2015|website=[https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/charity-commission Charity Commission]}}</ref>

The Trust makes grants to other charitable causes at the discretion of the trustees. It currently does not accept unsolicited applications for funding,<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.tolkientrust.org/ The Tolkien Trust]|articleurl=http://www.tolkientrust.org/applications.html|articlename=Applications|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> but does list a number of specific areas it supports:

{{blockquote|1. emergency and disaster relief<br/>2. overseas aid and development<br/>3. the homeless and refugees<br/>4. healthcare charities, especially those focusing on illnesses of childhood and old age, the needs of disadvantaged communities and medical research<br/>5. religious causes promoting peace and reconciliation and work with impoverished communities<br/>6. environmental causes<br/>7. education and the arts|[http://www.tolkientrust.org/about.html About The Tolkien Trust]}}

===Litigation===
From [[2003]] and [[2006]] the Trust and The [[Tolkien Estate]] demanded royalties from [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' films]].<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.worldcrunch.com/ World Crunch]|articleurl=http://www.worldcrunch.com/culture-society/my-father-039-s-quot-eviscerated-quot-work-son-of-hobbit-scribe-j.r.r.-tolkien-finally-speaks-out/hobbit-silmarillion-lord-of-rings/c3s10299/#.VZvG9FKOZb0|articlename=My Father's "Eviscerated" Work - Son Of Hobbit Scribe J.R.R. Tolkien Finally Speaks Out|dated=5 December 2012|author=Raphaëlle Rérolle|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> Following claims from [[New Line Cinema]] that the films failed to make a profit, on [[11 February]] [[2008]] The Tolkien Trust, The [[Tolkien Estate]] and [[HarperCollins]] filed a lawsuit seeking at least $150 million (7.5% of gross revenue) in damages. They accused New Line Cinema of "unabashed and insatiable greed" and the "infamous practice of creative 'Hollywood accounting'."<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.guardian.co.uk The Guardian]|dated=12 February 2008|articleurl=http://film.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,2255880,00.html|articlename=Tolkien heirs sue Lord of the Rings studio for $150m|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> The claim, which also attempted to stop production of the [[The Hobbit (film series)|forthcoming ''Hobbit'' films]], was concluded on [[8 September]] [[2009]] with an out-of-court settlement.<ref>{{webcite|author=Alex Dobuzinskis|articleurl=http://www.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idUSTRE5875BK20090908|articlename=Legal settlement clears way for 'Hobbit' movie|website=[http://www.reuters.com Reuters]|dated=8 September 2009|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> [[Christopher Tolkien]] said that they "regret that legal action was necessary, but are glad that this dispute has been settled on satisfactory terms"<ref>{{webcite|articleurl=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2009/09/new-line-resolves-lawsuit-with-tolkien-trust-and-harpercollins-over-lord-of-rings-.html|author=Claudia Eller|dated=8 September 2009|articlename=New Line resolves lawsuit with Tolkien Trust and HarperCollins over 'Lord of the Rings'|website=[http://latimes.com/ Los Angeles Times]|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> and that "New Line may now proceed with its proposed films of 'The Hobbit'", whilst their lawyer said that they "feel vindicated and are entirely satisfied with the terms of the settlement." Alan Horn, president of [[Warner Bros.]] (owners of New Line Cinema) said "we all look forward to a mutually productive and beneficial relationship in the future".<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://latimes.com/ Los Angeles Times]|articleurl=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/sep/09/business/fi-ct-hobbit9|articlename=Warner Bros. settles lawsuit over 'Lord of the Rings' licensing payments|dated=9 September 2009|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> Although both sides refused to reveal the size of settlement - simply saying that the Tolkien Trust would receive a "significant portion" - the Trust's accounts reveal that in [[2009]] and [[2010]] it received £24 million and £1.6 million respectively in film rights,<ref name="Accounts2009"/><ref name="Accounts2010"/> and in [[2011]] it received £603,515 in merchandising rights.<ref name="Accounts2011"/>

On the [[19 November]] [[2012]], Priscilla Tolkien as a trustee of The Tolkien Trust, [[Tolkien Estate|The Tolkien Estate]] and [[HarperCollins]] ("the plaintiffs") filed a lawsuit against [[Warner Bros.]], [[New Line Cinema]] and the [[Saul Zaentz Company]] ("the defendants") seeking damages of $80 million.<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/ The Telegraph]|articleurl=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/9691966/JRR-Tolkiens-daughter-sues-producers-of-The-Hobbit.html|articlename=JRR Tolkien's daughter sues producers of The Hobbit|dated=20 November 2012|author=Raf Sanchez|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> They claimed that Tolkien's copyright had been breached and that the defendants had no right to sell themed slot machines and downloadable video games; in the claim the plaintiffs state: "Not only does the production of gambling games patently exceed the scope of defendants' rights, but this infringing conduct has outraged Tolkien's devoted fan base, causing irreparable harm to Tolkien's legacy and reputation and the valuable goodwill generated by his works."<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/ The Daily Mail]|articleurl=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2236141/Tolkien-family-sues-The-Hobbit-movie-makers-80m.html|articlename=Trouble in the shire: Tolkien family sues movie makers for $80MILLION over 'Hobbit' trilogy merchandizing|dated=21 November 2012|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> They assert that the merchandising rights only extend to physical, and not electronic, products.<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/ The Daily Mail]|articleurl=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2293844/Tolkien-family-Warner-Bros-prepare-legal-battle-Lord-Rings-fruit-machines.html|author=Daniel Miller|articlename=Gambling's a really bad hobbit: Tolkien family and Warner Bros at war over Lord of the Rings fruit machines|dated=15 March 2013|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> On [[11 March]] [[2013]], Saul Zaentz and Warner Bros. filed counter-claims against the plaintiffs (including The Tolkien Trust) arguing that as a result of the Estate's actions the defendants had lost out on merchandising income, and that there has been a breach of good-faith by the Estate and the Trust.<ref>{{webcite|website=[http://www.theonering.net/ TheOnering.net]|author=Kelvarhin|articleurl=http://www.theonering.net/torwp/2013/07/16/75725-making-sense-of-the-latest-tolkien-lawsuit/|articlename=Making Sense of the latest Tolkien Lawsuit|dated=16 July 2013|accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref>

==Copyrights==
The primary assets of The Tolkien Trust are the copyrights to certain works by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] which continue to provide income to the Trust. The assets held by The Tolkien Trust are a number of (many posthumous) publications by J.R.R. Tolkien:<ref name="Accounts2009"/>
* ''[[Beowulf: A Translation and Commentary]]''<ref name="Accounts2013"/>
* ''[[The Fall of Arthur]]''<ref name="Accounts2013"/>
* ''[[The Legend of Sigurd and Gudrún]]''
* Renewal copyrights in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' in the USA
* ''[[Mythopoeia]]''
* ''[[Roverandom]]''
* ''[[Smith of Wootton Major]]''
* Author royalties from ''[[The Tolkien Family Album]]''
* 40% of the renewal copyrights in ''[[The Tolkien Reader]]'' in the USA
* ''[[Tree and Leaf]]''
* "published editions of various philological writings and fragments"<ref name="Accounts2013"/>

The Trust also holds a number of sundry assets:
* Letters from Tolkien to A.B.M. Ronald and C. Martin (see "[[Letter to Amy Ronald (15 March 1969)]]" and "[[Letter to Amy Ronald (20 March 1969)]]")
* Posters drawn by [[Pauline Baynes]]
* "Certain unpublished papers, letters, artistic works, pictures, photographs and other documents originally forming part of the Estate of J R R Tolkien, and the copyright in such materials formerly owned by the Estate."<ref name="Accounts2013"/>

==Finances==
The Trust does not partake in any fund-raising activity: all income received constitute royalties from copyrights and subsequent investments. Although the Trust holds literary assets no value is provided for them on the grounds that it would not be "practical and cost-effective"; as such, the primary assets of the Trust are cash and investments ([[wikipedia:Bond (finance)|bonds]] and [[wikipedia:Share (finance)|shares]]). The Trust has an [[wikipedia:Socially responsible investing|ethical investment policy]] so has no investment in tobacco, or the manufacture of armaments.<ref name="Accounts2009"/> In [[2012]], gambling services was added to the list of investments the Trust would not hold.<ref name="Accounts2012"/>

The Trust was founded on [[1 April]] [[1977]] and its financial year was the same as the [[wikipedia:Fiscal year#United Kingdom|United Kingdom's fiscal year]] for individuals ([[6 April]] - [[5 April]]). In [[2013]] the existed unincorporated charity was closed and its assets transferred to a new [[wikipedia:Charitable incorporated organisation|charitable incorporated organisation]]; the new charity's financial year is the same as the calendar year.<ref name="Accounts2013"/>
